description: Borrowed from French clôture (“closure”). Doublet of closure and clausure.

entries.meaning: (law, politics, chiefly US) In legislative assemblies that permit unlimited debate (that is, a filibuster): a motion, procedure or rule by which debate is ended so that a vote may be taken on the matter. For example, in the United States Senate, a three-fifths majority vote of the body is required to invoke cloture and terminate debate.

verbs.description: cloture (third-person singular simple present clotures, present participle cloturing, simple past and past participle clotured)

entries.meaning: To end legislative debate by this means.
